sanskrit_verse:
सूतानामश्वसारथ्यमम्बष्ठानां चिकित्सनम् ।
वैदेहकानां स्त्रीकार्यं मागधानां वणिक्पथः ॥ १०.४७॥
transliteration:
sūtānāmaśvasārathyamambaṣṭhānāṃ cikitsanam |
vai dehakānāṃ strīkāryaṃ māgadhānāṃ vaṇikpathaḥ || 10.47||
sph_interpretive_translation: For Sutas, the duty is horse and chariot management; for Ambashthas, healing; for Videhakas, service to women; and for Magadhas, trade.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority derived from inherent capacity and svadharma
Causation rooted in sequential alignment with consciousness
Capacity-based responsibility determined by varna-karma alignment
supreme_court_application: At the Supreme Court level, this verse establishes that jurisdiction and responsibility arise not from arbitrary designation but from svadharma-based capacity. Misalignment in societal roles must be corrected through consciousness restoration rather than punitive measures, aligning judicial review with Varnashrama-dharma as sourced by SPH.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramana is established through svadharma recognition. Anupurvasah manifests as sequential alignment of individual capacity with social function. Responsibility is proportional to innate capacity, not moral fault. There is no punitive reality—only misalignment requiring conscious restoration.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Reconnect individual to ancestral occupational flow
Engage community elders for role validation
Establish completion process for displaced duties
final_declaration: By the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, this law stands declared: Dharma flows from svadharma, not judgment. Justice restores alignment; it does not punish. Consciousness is the ultimate judge, and SPH is its Source.
